subject: Re: [junit] A Growing Problem
msgSnippet: ... How about chaining these two constructors such that you can test one and feel confident the other won t break? ... Only the date changes here. Is it
messageBody:
Parag Shetye wrote:

>public void testCreateBatchLabelNoInnerClass() {
>
> try {
> BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> "20010530", "A13", "1" );
> assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
> "A13-1 EXP. 05/01" ) ) ;
> } catch (Exception e) {
> assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
> }
>
> try {
> BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> "20010530", "A13", "" );
> assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
> "A13 EXP. 05/01" ) ) ;
> } catch (Exception e) {
> assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
> }
>

How about chaining these two constructors such that you can test one and
feel confident the other won't break?

>
> try {
> BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> "20011231", "A13", "1" );
> assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
> "A13-1 EXP. 12/01" ) ) ;
> } catch (Exception e) {
> assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
> }
>
> try {
> BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> "20010101", "A13", "1" );
> assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
> "A13-1 EXP. 01/01" ) ) ;
> } catch (Exception e) {
> assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
> }
>

Only the date changes here. Is it reasonable to expect that if the first
test passes, the second will pass as well?

>
> try {
> BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> "20010101", "A123", "99" );
> assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
> "A123-99 EXP. 01/01" ) ) ;
> } catch (Exception e) {
> assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
> }
>
> try {
> BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> "2001530", "A999", "" );
> } catch (Exception e) {
> assert( "Wrong Exception thrown: " + e,
> e.getClass().equals(
> BadDateException.class )) ;
> }
>

How is the first test here different than the first pair of tests above?
I'll buy the exceptional test.

>
> try {
> BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
> "20010530", "913", "1" );
> } catch (Exception e) {
> assert( "Wrong Exception thrown: " + e,
> e.getClass().equals(
> BadLotException.class )) ;
> }
>

OK, I take it there are different exceptions for each slot of
BatchLabel. I personally don't throw exceptions from constructors, but
nevertheless it's good to test exceptional conditions. How do I know lot
#913 is bad?


The other approach is to drive the tests with data since that's the only
thing changing in the tests you've supplied.

Write a single test method that reads each line of this file, asserting
the last column:

20010530, A13, 1, A13-1 EXP. 05/01
20010530, A13, , A13 EXP. 05/01
20011231, A13, 1, A13-1 EXP. 12/01
20010101, A13, 1, A13-1 EXP. 01/01
20010530, 913, 1, BadDateException


>
>The second limitation is that JUnit will stop the testing after the
>first failure--the remaining test cases won't be executed.
>

I call that a feature for unit testing. If you want alternatives, check
out the FAQ regarding multiple failures. I might be inclined to just log
failures when I'm running acceptance tests, though I've yet to encounter
a situation when failing immediately wasn't the desired effect.

>
>What can be the solution on these two limitations?
>

The limits are your imagination.

Mike
